Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was getting ready for the family puja. I glanced at the screen and saw a message from Priya: “Ugh, today was endless. Can I vent for a bit?” I knew she’d had a rough week, and as her friend, I wanted to be there for her, to listen and offer comfort like I always did. But my mother was already calling from the hallway, reminding me to hurry up and change into my kurta. The ceremony was about to start, and being late would be disrespectful—not just to my family, but to the traditions I’d grown up with. I stared at Priya’s message, feeling the weight of her need for support, while also feeling the pull of my family’s expectations. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be a good friend and a good Hindu at the same time, torn between two worlds that both mattered deeply to me.
